author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md) and the [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). The following guidelines were not met:

- Name does not meet all of the following: starts with an upper-case letter, ASCII alphanumerics only, not all letters are upper-case.
- Name is not at least 5 characters long
- Package name similar to 7 existing packages.
  1. Similar to SIAN. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  2. Similar to SEAL. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  3. Similar to STFT. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  4. Similar to FLAC. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  5. Similar to SHA. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  6. Similar to SMC. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  7. Similar to Stan. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 1 between lowercased names is at or below cutoff of 1.

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simple retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

On popular demand (ok, somebody else and me :-) ), I am again attempting to register this package under the name STAC. The previous [attempt](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/59089) was not successful as that package name is too short. For reference these are the reasons I would like to use the name STAC:

The name STAC was chosen because the package implements the [STAC specification](https://stacspec.org/) where STAC stands for SpatioTemporal Asset Catalog. STAC.jl is similar to the python module [pySTAC](https://pypi.org/project/pystac/).

The standard specifies several types like (catalog, item, assets,...) which are available in Julia as `STAC.Catalog`, `STAC.Item`, `STAC.Asset` (the types `Catalog`, `Item` and `Asset` are not explicitly exported). A short module name is desirable in my opinion.

(copied from https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/59089#issuecomment-1108567359 )

In addition, I think that the STAC protocol has a promising future because there are several earth observation data providers using it (and it is always referred as "STAC"), like:

* [NASA Common Metadata Repository](https://wiki.earthdata.nasa.gov/display/ED/CMR+SpatioTemporal+Asset+Catalog+%28CMR-STAC%29+Documentation)
* [Registry of Open Data on AWS](https://registry.opendata.aws/)
* [Microsoft Planetary Computer Catalog](https://planetarycomputer.microsoft.com/docs/quickstarts/reading-stac/)

Don't worry, this will be my last attempt to use register this package as STAC.

[noblock]

One way to have a short name for users (who know what it is) calling, without inflicting another acronym on non-users (who have no idea) is to export a symbol like `const STAC = SpatioTemporalAssetCatalog`. 

An example of this is https://github.com/JuliaMath/IntelVectorMath.jl, previously VML.jl (an acronym known to those who use it, but in fact deprecated upstream) but now a nice long name that's fairly obvious if it shows up in logs / tests etc. to be decoded by people who don't use it.
Thanks for the suggestion @mcabbott ! If possible, I would still prefer STAC as package name, so that this package behave like most other package concerning the namespace.

body:
